Hello,

My refactoring of JNeat has brought me to the speciation code, and I'm
finding it tricky to reconcile the JNeat speciation code with descriptions
in NEAT papers and discussion in this forum.  There is a lot going on here,
but I think I can state the problem simply without getting into the details
of the JNeat code.

Ken's paper describes speciation as occuring every generation.  Speciation
entails iterating over the population, and performing some rudimentary
clustering using a compatibility function and threshhold.  Pretty
straightforward.

Indeed, this algorithm is implemented in JNeat as the speciate() method, but
its only invoked at the beginning of evolution and never again!  The growth
and death of species afterwards is determined by some code in the epoch()
method that does not appear to resemble NEAT speciation.  I'm concerned that
whatever JNeat is doing, it isn't what Ken had in mind, and it leads to some
strange behavior.  Attached is a graph showing how the number of species
grows during a run of the XOR experiment.  With a population size of 500, it
increases almost monotonically to 400 before leveling off after 40
generations.

Shouldn't the speciate() method be called after ever generation/epoch?
 Isn't this way too many species?  Approximately how many species would you
expect for the XOR experiment with 500 individuals?


Regards,
Daniel

--000e0cd25ac2839b5e0481285ae9
